Hi,
   Since the entropy and enthalpy are monotonic functions of T, I could=

probably change the solution algorithm to a root finder algorithm rather
t=
han the Newton's method that is currently being employed. Newton's
method r=
igorously requires that the first derivative be continuous for
convergence =
to be achieved. This in turn requires that Cp and H and/or S
be continuous =
at temperature boundaries. This is normally the case, and
a warning message=
 is printed out if it isn't the case. However, the
question then becomes to=
 what degree are these functions continuous
across temperature boundaries a=
nd can one then make a statement about
how "continuous" they have to be in =
order for the setState_HP and
setState_SP functions to converge for all cas=
es. 
   A root finder algorithm has less requirements on the smoothness of
=
the function than a Newton's method algorithm. So, it should be more
robust=
.

   Also, I could expose the convergence requirements for these two
funct=
ions in the matlab levels. Currently, they are exposed at the C++
level wit=
h defaults on dT of 1.0E-4.

Best wishes,
Harry Moffat

e_SP
Error:   no convergence. dt =3D 0.000219057

I feel like my research h=
as become a game of roulette!  I am using
Cantera  from within Matlab, wher=
e I solve systems of compressors and
turbines.  It works great most of the =
time!  However when my code asks
Cantera to setState_SP (entropy and Pressu=
re) or set_State_HP and this
state fall sufficiently close to 1000K, Canter=
a crashes.  I know I could
fudge my quarry in the hopes I don't land on a 1=
000K condition but I
would rather know my code (and Cantera) are rock stabl=
e.

I believe this is happening because of the NASA polynomials switching
c=
oefficients at 1000K, and while the polynomials are close to each
other, th=
e setState function requires 10^-8 accuracy (way more than I
require).

I a=
m hoping someone else has solved this problem or can offer
assistance.   
M=
y current thought is to find the function(s) where the polynomial  
coeffic=
ients are chosen for the appropriate temperature range.   Then
add  
a case=
 such that between T =3D 999 and 1001 a new polynomial will be  
interpolat=
ed and used for the subsequent thermo calculations.   
Unfortunately I have=
 yet to find which functions these are and deduce if
this may really work/h=
elp?

Your help will be greatly appreciated,
Winston Burbank
ftwsb@...
